awd_titl_txt: Quantum Phase Measurement and Metrology using Four-Wave Mixing
awd_abstract_narration:
Precision optical measurements are limited in sensitivity and resolution by the noise on the light used to make them.  In everyday life a classical description of light usually suffices.  However taking this approach leads to limitations on the sensitivity of measurements that are not fundamental.  If one uses a quantum mechanical description of the light, then one can envision "non-classical" light fields that will lead to more sensitive measurements than with "classical" light.  This extra sensitivity can be used for ultrasensitive detection in defense applications and is especially useful at very low light levels.   Thus it is interesting in the field of imaging of live biological tissues where one would like to avoid damage to the tissue. This project will use the non-linear optical properties of certain materials to create non-classical light and investigate how much advantage over the limits for classical light can be achieved.  In particular, this team has demonstrated an optical phase measurement device that has more sensitivity to length changes than a "classical" interferometer using a laser source. The group will further investigate the design of different quantum-based phase measurement devices and study what aspects of these approaches lead to better measurements. 

Non-classical light, which has different noise statistics than classical light, will allow this team to make measurements with noise levels that are below those obtainable with a coherent state or other "nearly classical" optical fields.  The use of intrinsically quantum states in metrological applications, such as interferometry, will allow the group to improve such measurements beyond what can be obtained with classical light. This team studies how to take advantage of quantum states for noise reduction and demonstrate the usefulness and/or limitations of these states. In particular, this project is centered on studying phase-measurement devices based on "active-media", with gain or stimulated loss.  The team will study seeded versions, based on phase measurements using an amplified seed beam, as well as unseeded versions, based on the use of spontaneous emission alone.  They plan to both look at these interferometers as phase measurement tools, and as a means to study the quantum states that are internal to these devices.  In terms of the quantum states, they will study the effect of directly modulating a quantum state, and in particular, modulating one mode of a two-mode squeezed state.

por.por_cntn:
The intent of the project was to study how to take advantage of quantum states of light for noise reduction in phase measurements (in an interferometer where we interfere and compare the phase of two beams).  In particular, we looked at phase-measurement devices based on "active-media," that is, with gain or stimulated loss in a nonlinear-optical medium inside the device. In this case the medium is a nonlinear 4-wave-mixing process in an atomic-vapor. We looked at these interferometers both as phase measurement tools, and as a means to study the quantum states that are created inside these devices. We also investigated quantum phase-tracking (following a changing phase) with these devices.  

 A nonlinear “truncated” SU(1,1) interferometer has been constructed; this is a device to measure phase using 2-mode quantum “squeezed” light where the phase of two beams generated in a nonlinear process are highly correlated.  (The label “SU(1,1)” refers to a mathematical group symmetry name that indicates that active gain or loss is involved.) With this device we have demonstrated the ability to make phase measurements that are sub-shot-noise by more than a factor of 2 – that is, better by this factor than one can do with an equivalent amount of classical light; for example, light from a laser.  We also studied how to optimize the measurements and investigated where improvements in the system can be made.  The limitations of our system have been explored in some detail and it has been determined that the homodyne contrast with the local oscillator (the beam overlap between the signal beam and a reference measurement beam) is the main limiting factor. We have examined how to improve the level of measured squeezing in such homodyne measurements and we have explored the use of a spatial light modulator, much like the modulators used in projection televisions, to optimize the local oscillator beam overlap in the homodyne measurement.  In addition, we implemented a method of phase-tracking in the experiment and studied how different mathematical phase-tracking algorithms would work in this system.

Our objective was to improve the sensitivity of the nonlinear interferometer and to be able to make adaptive phase measurements with it. We demonstrated the ability to improve such measurements by more than a factor of two by using non-classical light. Finally, we worked to improve the homodyne measurements of squeezing (noise reduction) in our system and to extend the system to work at low (acoustic) frequencies, which are presently limited by various sources of technical noise.

Two graduate students have been partially supported on this grant. In addition, a visiting professor has spent summers with our group and also brought undergraduate researchers from his home institution  to work in the group over the summers.  The students, both graduate and undergraduate, have participated in forefront research and interacted with postdoctoral scholars and senior researchers. We have encouraged participation in all aspects of our work and the students have been able to present the results of their work at professional meetings.
